member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Controls.Callout
member.summary: Renders a callout shape supporting several shapes combined with a callout arrow.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Controls.CompositeContentShape
member.summary: Provides a base class of a composite shape that derives from and implements .
member.remarks:
implements interface, and supports rendering a geometry similar to , but the geometry can be rendered outside of layout boundary.
A typical implementation will have a customized default template in generic.xaml which template-binds most shape properties to a . It should also extend the property to customize the appearance of the .
This class also supports showing content together with the shape.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters
member.summary: Provides an interface to discribe the parameters of a Shape.
member.remarks: This interface is the data for communication between Shape and GeometrySource. Typically a concrete implementation of IShape will implements this interface and pass it into GeometrySource.UpdateGeometry(), who will consume the shape as readonly data provider.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IShape
member.summary: Provides the necessary interface to define a Shape. Both primitive and composite shapes need to match this interface, although they might derive from different type of FrameworkElement.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IShape.InvalidateGeometry

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.ArcToBezier(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double,System.Double,System.Windows.Point[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: ArcToBezier, Compute the Bezier approximation of an arc Adopted from MIL:Graphics\core\geometry\utils.cpp
member.remarks:
This utility computes the Bezier approximation for an elliptical arc as it is defined in the SVG arc spec. The ellipse from which the arc is carved is axis-aligned in its own coordinates, and defined there by its x and y radii. The rotation angle defines how the ellipse's axes are rotated relative to our x axis. The start and end points define one of 4 possible arcs; the sweep and large-arc flags determine which one of these arcs will be chosen. See SVG spec for details.
Returning cPieces = 0 indicates a line instead of an arc cPieces = -1 indicates that the arc degenerates to a point

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.GetArcAngle(System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Get the number of Bezier arcs, and sine/cosine of each. Adopted from MIL:Graphics\core\geometry\utils.cpp
member.remarks: This is a private utility used by ArcToBezier. We break the arc into pieces so that no piece will span more than 90 degrees. The input points are on the unit circle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.GetBezierDistance(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: GetBezierDistance, return the distance as a fraction of the radius Adopted from MIL:Graphics\core\geometry\utils.cpp
member.remarks:
Get the distance from a circular arc's endpoints to the control points of the Bezier arc that approximates it, as a fraction of the arc's radius.
Since the result is relative to the arc's radius, it depends strictly on the arc's angle. The arc is assumed to be of 90 degrees of less, so the angle is determined by the cosine of that angle, which is derived from rDot = the dot product of two radius vectors. We need the Bezier curve that agrees with the arc's points and tangents at the ends and midpoint. Here we compute the distance from the curve's endpoints to its control points.
Since we are looking for the relative distance, we can work on the unit circle. Place the center of the circle at the origin, and put the X axis as the bisector between the 2 vectors. Let a be the angle between the vectors. Then the X coordinates of the 1st and last points are cos(a/2). Let x be the X coordinate of the 2nd and 3rd points. At t=1/2 we have a point at (1,0). But the terms of the polynomial there are all equal:
(1-t)^3 = t*(1-t)^2 = t^2*(1-t) = t^3 = 1/8,
so from the Bezier formula there we have:
1 = (1/8) * (cos(a/2) + 3x + 3x + cos(a/2)),
hence
x = (4 - cos(a/2)) / 3
The X difference between that and the 1st point is:
DX = x - cos(a/2) = 4(1 - cos(a/2)) / 3.
But DX = distance / sin(a/2), hence the distance is
dist = (4/3)*(1 - cos(a/2)) / sin(a/2).
Rather than the angle a, we are given rDot = R^2 * cos(a), so we multiply top and bottom by R:
dist = (4/3)*(R - Rcos(a/2)) / Rsin(a/2)
and use some trig: ________________ cos(a/2) = \/(1 + cos(a)) / 2 ______________________ R*cos(a/2) = \/(R^2 + R^2 cos(a)) / 2 ________________ = \/(R^2 + rDot) / 2
Let A = (R^2 + rDot)/2. ____________________ R*sin(a/2) = \/R^2 - R^2 cos^2(a/2) _______ = \/R^2 - A
so: _ 4 R - \/A dist = - * ------------ 3 _______ \/R^2 - A
History: 5/29/2001 MichKa Created it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PathSegmentHelper.ArcToBezierHelper.AcceptRadius(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@)
member.summary: Adopted from MIL:Graphics\core\geometry\utils.cpp Return false if the radius is too small compared to the chord length (returns true on NaNs) radius is modified to the value that's accepted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener
member.summary: A utility class to flatten Bezier curves.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener.FlattenCubic(System.Windows.Point[],System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Windows.Point},System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Flattens a Bezier cubic curve and adds the result polyline to the third parameter.
member.param: The maximum distance between two corresponding points on the true curve and on the flattened polyline. Must be strictly positive.
Where to add the flattened polyline.

True to skip the first control point when adding the flattened polyline. Where to add the value of the Bezier curve parameter associated to each of the polyline vertices If is empty, the first control point and its associated parameter are always added.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.BezierCurveFlattener.FlattenQuadratic(System.Windows.Point[],System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Windows.Point},System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Double})
member.summary: Flattens a Bezier quadratic curve and adds the result polyline to the third parameter. We use degree elevation for Bezier curves to reuse the code for the cubic case.
member.param: The maximum distance between two corresponding points on the true curve and on the flattened polyline. Must be strictly positive.
Where to add the flattened polyline.

Whether to skip the first control point when adding the flattened polyline. Where to add the value of the Bezier curve parameter associated to each of the polyline vertices If is empty, the first control point and its associated parameter are always added.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData
member.summary: Represent a polyline consist with a list of connecting points. A closed polygon is represented by repeating the first point at the end. The differences, normals, angles, and lengths are computed on Demand.

member.summary: Construct a polyline with two or more points.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.IsClosed
member.summary: The polyline is closed when first and last point is repeated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Count
member.summary: The count of points in this polyline

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.TotalLength
member.summary: The total arc length of this polyline

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Points
member.summary: The point array of this polyline

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Differences
member.summary: The forward difference vector of polyline. Points[i] + Differences[i] = Points[i+1]

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Lengths
member.summary: The length between line segments, Points[i] to Points[i+1]

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Normals
member.summary: The list of normal vectors on each point, bisect direction between 2 difference vectors. Each vector is normalized.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.Angles
member.summary: The list of Cos(angle) between 2 line segments on point p[i] Note: The value is cos(angle) = Dot(u, v). It's not in degree.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData.AccumulatedLength
member.summary: The list of accumulated length from points[i] to points[0]

member.summary: The reason why this location is sampled.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Index
member.summary: The index of the point on polyline point list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Ratio
member.summary: Ratio: [0, 1], which is always before / (before + after)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Before
member.summary: Arc length before stop point. It's non-negative, and less than Length[index]

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.After
member.summary: Arc length after the stop point. It's non-negative, and less than Length[index]

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation.Remain
member.summary: Remaining length within a step to hit next stop. Positive to go forward. Negative to go backward.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper
member.summary: Helper class to work with list of points

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper.PathMarch(Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData,System.Double,System.Double,System.Func{Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.MarchLocation,System.Double})
member.summary: March the given polyline with given interval and output each stop through callback
member.param: The polyline points to march on
The arc length to march before stopping at the first point.
The max angle between edges to be considered a corner vertex
Callback when marching algorithm stop at a point. The callback returns the arc length for next stop. If the asked length is negative, march backwards. If callback returns NaN, finish marching.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineHelper.GetWrappedPolylines(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Expression.Drawing.Core.PolylineData},System.Double@)
member.summary: Reorders the given list of polylines so that the polyline a given arclength into the list is the first. Polylines that preceded this line are concatenated to the end of the list, with the first polyline at the very end.
member.param: The arclength into the entire list of polylines at which to find the start line. The arc length into that line is returned in this variable.
member.returns: The reordered and wrapped list.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.GeometrySource`1
member.summary: Provides the base class of a source of geometry. It generate and cache the geometry based on input parameters and layout bounds.
member.remarks: A typical implementation will extend the UpdateCachedGeometry() to update this.cachedGeometry. This base class will then handle the invalidation, pipeline to geometry effects and caching realtive to layout bounds. An implementation should try to reuse the cached geometry as much as possible to avoid reconstruction in rendering thread. An implementation can extend the ComputeLogicalBounds to handle Stretch differently.
member.typeparam: The type of geometry source parameter on which the base class is working on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource
member.summary: Provides an interface to describe the source of a geometry.
member.remarks: This interface is designed to expose geometry source in a non-generic way. Typical implementation should subclass GeometrySource<> instead of implementing this interface directly.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.InvalidateGeometry
member.summary: Notify the geometry is invalidated because of external changes.
member.remarks: Typically geometry is invalidated when parameters are changed. If any geometry has been invalidated externally, geometry will be recomputed regardless bounds' change.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.UpdateGeometry(Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySourceParameters,System.Windows.Rect)
member.summary: Update the geometry using given parameter and layout bounds. Returns false if nothing has been updated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.Geometry
member.summary: Gets or sets the result geometry after the latest UpdateGeometry()

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.LogicalBounds
member.summary: Gets the bounding box where geometry should stretch to. The actual geometry might be smaller or larger than this. should already take stroke thickness and stretch into consideration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Media.IGeometrySource.LayoutBounds
member.summary: Gets the actuall bound of FrameworkElement. includes logical bounds, stretch and stroke thickness.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Expression.Media.ShapeImplementation.ShouldForceResetRenderGeometryProperty
member.summary:
Fix 95808: Changing sub DPs on same instance of RenderedGeometry won't trigger a silverlight redraw, when and only when the type is converting from an unreferenced type to referenced one inside Blend. The workaround is to reset RenderedGeometry in this case. This logic will only be run once for entire life time.
Fix 96240: Changing sub DPs inside PolylineSegment.Points sometimes won't trigger redraw, example is Callout.AnchorPoint. Extend the silverlight workaround to all and force reset render geometry.
This property is controled by DrawingPropertyMetadataOptions.ForceResetGeometry

member.summary: Renderes an Arc shape supporting Arc, Ring and Pie mode controled by ArcThickness.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape
member.summary: Platform neutral implementation of Shape deriving from WPF:Shape or SL:Path
Provides Silverlight implementation of PrimitiveShape who derives from platform Path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.CreateGeometrySource
member.summary: Extend how the shape is drawn with creating geometry source

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.InvalidateGeometry
member.summary: Invalidates the geometry for a . After the invalidation, the will recompute the geometry, which will occur asynchronously.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.MeasureOverride(System.Windows.Size)
member.summary: Provides the behavior for the Measure pass of Silverlight layout. Classes can override this method to define their own Measure pass behavior.
member.returns: The size that this object determines it needs during layout, based on its calculations of child object allotted sizes, or possibly on other considerations such as fixed container size.
member.param: The available size that this object can give to child objects. Infinity () can be specified as a value to indicate that the object will size to whatever content is available.
member.remarks:
In WPF, measure override works from Shape.DefiningGeometry which is not always as expected see bug 99497 for details where WPF is not having correct measure by default.
In Silverlight, measure override on Path does not work the same as primitive shape works.
We should return the smallest size this shape can correctly render without clipping. By default a shape can render as small as a dot, therefore returning the strokethickness.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.ArrangeOverride(System.Windows.Size)
member.summary: Provides the behavior for the Arrange pass of Silverlight layout. Classes can override this method to define their own Arrange pass behavior.
member.returns: The actual size used once the element is arranged in layout.
member.param: The final area within the parent that this object should use to arrange itself and its children.
member.remarks: will recompute the Geometry when it's invalidated and update the RenderedGeometry, and GeometryMargin.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.OnSizeChanged(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Windows.DependencyPropertyChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: In Silverlight, when Path is inside a Canvas, layout notifications are disabled. We cannot get Measure/ArrangeOverride, nor SizeChanged event. The only way to get notification is data binding to Width/Height property. Because ActualWidth/ActualHeight does not work in data binding either.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.GeometryMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin between logical bounds and actual geometry bounds. This can be either positive (as in ) or negative (as in ).

member.name: E:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.RenderedGeometryChanged
member.summary: Occurs when RenderedGeometry is changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.RenderedGeometry
member.summary: Gets or sets the rendered geometry of the primitive shape, mapping to in Silverlight.
member.remarks: The concept is corresponding to WPF Shape.RenderedGeometry. Silverlight must use DP for rendered geometry so that it updates correctly.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.PrimitiveShape.Data
member.summary: Gets or sets a that specifies the shape to be drawn.
member.returns: A description of the shape to be drawn.
member.remarks: A new Data property to hide Path.Data property, to avoid being serialized to xaml. This property will carry DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.Arc.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the start angle.
member.value: The start angle in degrees. 0 degree is pointing up.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.Arc.EndAngle

member.value: The end angle in degree. 0 degree is pointing up.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.Arc.ArcThickness

member.name: P:Microsoft.Expression.Shapes.Arc.ArcThicknessUnit
